description:
Coccidioides posadasii RMSCC 1037 is a dimorphic fungal species that belongs to the genus Coccidioides. It is one of the causative agents of coccidioidomycosis, a respiratory disease also known as Valley Fever.

The RMSCC 1037 strain is a clinical isolate of C. posadasii, which is a distinct species from the closely related C. immitis. C. posadasii is primarily found in the southwestern United States and parts of Mexico, while C. immitis is more prevalent in California.

In its mycelial form, C. posadasii RMSCC 1037 produces septate hyphae and arthroconidia, which are the infectious propagules. When inhaled, the arthroconidia transform into spherical endosporulating structures called spherules within the host's lungs. The spherules then rupture, releasing hundreds of endospores that can further disseminate and cause infection.

Coccidioides species are classified as dimorphic fungi, as they can exist in both a filamentous (mycelial) form and a spherical (parasitic) form, depending on the environmental conditions. This dimorphism is a crucial adaptation that allows the fungus to thrive in its natural soil habitat and to establish infection within the human host.

The RMSCC 1037 strain has been utilized in various research studies to understand the biology, epidemiology, and pathogenesis of coccidioidomycosis caused by C. posadasii.
